Turin Feb. 5. 1870.
Dear Jennie,
Here we are safe and comfortable at brother Eddie's. Anna stood the journey quite as well as we could expect. She feels pretty tired but does not think she has taken cold.
Your letter has not got here yet so, of course, we were not expected. but it is all just as well. They were both quite well. Eddie looks better than I have seen him in some time. Mate looks well but she has a little sore on her arm which troubles

her a good deal just now. She burned it Monday and took cold in it but it seems to be getting better now. Rahlie [?] is going to spend the evening with us. He called this afternoon and took tea and then went home and got his book so he could study and visit. He is looking very well and happy. I forgot to bring the letter than his folks sent for him. I thought certainly I put it in my jacket with the toothbrush, but must have left it on the bureau up stairs in our room. Rahlie wants his mother to come next week if she can. and he sends a special request to have her bring Maggie. He says he is anxious to see her. I will write

again in a day or two to let you know how Anne gets along. She is lying down now. Her food seems to taste good to her. We forgot to bring the powders? [?] Mary sent for Anna. I left them in a teacup on the table in the parlor. If you send the medicine please send Mary's letter too as Anne did not read it and I don't remember what she said about it. Love to all. Sarah A. Everett
Sunday evening. Anne feels quite tired but better than she did last night. I will write again soon. Tell Father that Eddie sent those H. books all right. -- Jennie,m we forgot to bring those circulars at the kniting [sic] machines. What shall we do? S.A.E.

New York June 17.1815
Dear Sister Jennie,
It is nearly dark but I thought I would commence a letter to you even if I am not able to finish it until tomorrow. We have a girl now, as I believe I told you, so I have more time to write than I did, though somehow I do not get at it very often. I had that P.O. order cashed today. I hope we shall be able to return your kindness sometime We do not spend much excepting for car unclear & c but that takes a good deal as you know. We cannot go much without taking the cars, and it does us good, especially the sick ones, to go out as often as we can. We hope we shall have enough now until

we go home unless we stay longer than we intend. Cynthia will need a little; enough to pay her may home and two or three dollars besides. She wrote off a list of her expences that mother may see how she spent what she had. which I will enclose. We feel a good deal encoureged about her. Four weeks ago last Tuesday she had the last hard spell. William too has been very much better this past week. She has not wheezed hardly any and he has been able to walk a good deal more. Yesterday we had a very pleasant ride and visit. We went to Mr. unclear Thomas' Jersey City. Mrs Jones and Rev Mr. Davies went with us. Eddie did not go on account of his school. The time will soon come for him to go home. He too will need money to pay his fare home. I hope it will not be very hard for you to spare so much. I must leave this now. William is going out for a little walk and I guess I will go with him.

Friday morning. We have had a nice rain this morning and it is raining some still. It was very much needed. I should think. We have not had much rain since we have been down. How is it with you? has it been very dry? It has been dry and cool here most of the time. William wants you to write more news. He says Mother writes the best letters of any of you. She tells how things are getting along. What interests you interests us. you know. I wish we could help you with the next unclear. but I hardly think we shall be with you then. As Cynthia and William seem to be gaining so nicely I think we ought to stay a little longer. We have not got Eddie a hat yet but we got a pair of shoes $2.50. we could not help getting them his old ones were all gone. Mary has not got herself any thing for summer, not even a hat., but she hopes to be able to in a few days. She has had a hard tug of it but things loak a little better. She is getting along nicely with practice: she is quite busy

and very successful. but pay is slow coming in. If you can spare the Heerald containing the account of the Anniversary exercises at Whitstown Sem. we should be very glad to see it. Has Jane Ann Williams visited with the Curch yet an is she waiting for the other girls? We were very glad to hear that they have come to the society. Are the prayer meetings well attended? I am glad you keep you class in Sunday school. How many does Anna have in her class? Are they going to have any thing the fourth of July? It is very lonely here when we do not hear from home for several days so please write as often as you can. Tell Mother that Eddie says he will talk enough when he gets home to make up for not writing. He is pretty busy and anxious now with his examinations. We are glad to unclear you tell her all the Steuben folks are getting along. Who bought Wm Reabert farm? With love to you all and to Laevers' folks from us all. I am as ever your aff. sister Sarah A.E.P.

New York July 27/75
Dear Sister Jennie,
We received a letter from Mother with a few words from you yesterday morning. Many thanks for the check. We were very glad to get it. Mr. Scott asked it so we had no trouble. I meant to have written yesterday, and now I will have to send a short letter as it is late, most tea time, and I want this to start today. Mary intended to have written to Mother and probably will soon. She is very busy with her practice and every thing else that she has on her hands. She has too much to do and especially too much care and anxiety. We were

glad to read John's letter. I enclose it in this. Mary intends to write to him soon. She and all of us think that Eddie ought not to go to Kansas if she cannot arrange things for him to come back here to school next year she says he ought to stay with Mother. is Frank going back next Fall? I do wish their home was not so far from all the rest of us. 
Cynthia is having severe sweating spells now far ahead a week something she had some years ago when she was beginning to gain unclear hope they are favorable. Her head seems to have less pressure when she sweats profusely. She is some weaker & her stomach troubles her some. Will write again. William is better than when I wrote last. 
Hastily yours, S.A.E.P.

Hillsdale Dec 7/76
Dear Jennie,
We were almost startled as well as relieved by hearing from home today. We were relieved as we had been anxiously expecting a letter for several days and we were startled by receiving three letters at once. Two of them were mailed the fifth and the sixth of Dec. This last one was from Mother and written Nov 30. I wonder if somebody forgot to put it in the mail? The other two were from you. We feel anxious and troubled about Anna. Poor child, she has been over taxing herself all last spring and summer

to say the least. How I wish I could see her and wait on her and comfort her a little. I am sorry Mary Jane is going to leave you so soon. I was in hopes you were going to have a good chance to rest. I feel thankful the ?ben in fairly off your hands. Of course you will miss it and feel lost and lonely without it at first, but it was too much of a burden especially as Anna is so feeble and tired out. I hope we did not do the wrong thing in coming away, I don't know as I could have started if i ha known she was going to be sick. William is pretty comfortable now. He went down town today and got our letters. He is feeling better now for a few days than he has since we came here. He breathes pretty freely and sleeps much better. He did not sleep much when he had the asthma so badly. We thought of staying a few

weeks longer to see how he would be and how we would like it here, especially as our friends here are so anxious to have us stay, but if you need us home or if you think we had better come sooner be sure and let us know. William says that he is very thankful to you all for saying that you would be glad to see us back again. I am glad to be able to be with Elizabeth a little and to help her some. She seems to enjoy having us here. They are all very kind and make us as comfortable as they can. I hope you are not very lonely; who sleeps in the study? Does Mr. Daves hoard at unclear and where is Stephen? Wm says 'Tell Anna she would be all right if she had me back in the study to keep the spooks off nights and to quarrel with er a little now and then.' he wants to know how Tom gets along and can he get

up without help? Wm wants to know if the family have moved into their new house back of the shed. I wonder if John Eddie remembers the little ?pasteboard thread unclear he made for Elizabeth in Lewistown? She had used it ever since and has got it yet. How does he get long in school? Is he most ready for college? have any of you seen our little new nephew? Please mention how they get along when you write. How is Frank ?Aura? Give our love to Jane Esther. Hattie is a good deal better but she is very weakly and does not have much appetite. I am glad you got some oysters for unclear They are 25 cents a can here. You must try to coax her to eat all she can and keep up good courage. We feel very thankful to you and Mother for writing to us so often. We shall be anxious now until we get another letter. It

here who lives in the fine woods now, and is much better of the asthma than when in Hillsdale. We intend to inquire more about him, but we do not feel very hopeful that Wm. would be much better there. I wish we were safe here in Steuben, but perhaps it is better as it is. We dread the journey a good deal this cold weather. They are building a temporary bridge at Ashtabula. I think they expect to have it ready so that the cars can pass over it in two or three weeks and perhaps sooner. the passengers, baggage & c. are now carried around in sleighs. We are having a long spell of pretty cold stormy weather even here in Mich. There has been good sleighing for several weeks. I think they had only about one week of sleighing last winter. It will probably be better for the fruit and crops next summer to have so much snow now. The

was two above zero this morning at sunrise. We had a hard spell with the asthma last Sat. and Sun. He is much better now and if it were pleasant he would be able to go out for a little walk, but it is too cold and stormy. My teeth are much better though they still pain me some. Elizabeth is about the same; some days very lame indeed and then a little better. On the whole we do not think she has got any worse for the last few weeks. I hope she will feel better when the warm weather comes and she can get out a little. How is it about the Cen. [?] our number has not come yet. We feel a little anxious lest the Chicago bag was an ill-fated train at Ashtabula and was burned. If so, it will be a great loss, but we hope it was not started soon enough for that. A good deal of the mail

was lost there as we see by the papers. Is there any word in Michigan who takes the Cen? William would be very glad if he could come across a welshman. Do they observe the work of prayer in our church? The weather is quite unfavorable, I find, at least it is here. I am glad Anna is able to ride out a little and that she is some better. How does Tim get along, going through the snow? Did Richard get a letter from William? Tell him that he wrote to him some time ago and we are expecting an answer.
Johnny expects to be married before a great while. - sometime in March I believe, to a Miss Bentley from Ohio. She was attending school here last term so we got some acquainted with her. She seems to be a pleasant kindhearted girl and we hope will make him a good wife. - How is Hugh fairs [?]
